Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Models of Cilia and Flagella in a Brinkman Fluid
Award.AbstractNarration:
Motile cilia and flagella are dynamic, elastic, biological structures that exhibit rhythmic motion. Through coordinated beating, cilia in the lung and respiratory tract help to clear the airway of potentially harmful particles and mucus. Impaired cilia motion can result in serious respiratory infection. This impairment can be caused by an altered fluid environment, a characteristic of cystic fibrosis, by defects in the cilia themselves as with primary ciliary dyskinesia, or by other respiratory diseases. Similarly, a sperm is only able to reach and fertilize an egg if its flagellum can propel it forward; impaired motility results in infertility. Cilia and sperm beating is highly dependent on the fluid environment, which contains fibrous, protein networks as well as chemical signals. Understanding this relationship between elastic structure and heterogeneous fluid is vital for development of delivery strategies for inhaled drugs and medicines, new contraceptives, and aiding in infertility due to reduced sperm motility. This project will focus on the development of new computational models and numerical methods that account for these fibrous, protein networks within the fluid to infer in vivo behavior of cilia and sperm.

Recent experiments have shown that i) sperm-flagella waveforms are altered when immersed in fluids containing networks of large proteins and also with flagellar calcium concentration, ii) the previously-considered `watery' fluid surrounding airway cilia actually contains a network of large proteins, or, 'brush'. This project will focus on identifying emergent waveforms of sperm flagella and airway cilia when nonplanar bending and internal flagellar biochemistry are taken into account. Cilia and flagella will be modeled as slender, elastic, structures immersed in a fluid governed by the Brinkman equation. A regularized framework and fundamental solutions will be used to derive new numerical methods for various confined geometries. The new numerical methods will be computationally-efficient and developed for use on high-performance computing systems. This research will identify factors that modulate sperm progression towards the egg, explore various waveforms of cilia and sperm, and investigate how a 'brush' in the fluid surrounding cilia might affect transport of particles within that fluid.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Interaction between dynamic elastic structures and a surrounding fluid is inherent in many biological settings, including sperm navigation towards an egg and cilia beating within the airways of the human lungs. Theoretical models of sperm motility and ciliary beating have typically only considered prescribed, planar waveforms in a purely viscous and homogeneous fluid. However, oviductal and vaginal fluid is non-homogeneous, containing networks of proteins and fibers with density that varies with the menstrual cycle. From laboratory experiments, it is known that flagellar waveforms (patterns of the sperm ‘tail’) and swimming speeds of sperm change in gels with different amounts of such proteins. Thus, the main focus of this research was to develop new computational methods that could be used to study elastic structures such as sperm, bacteria, and cilia moving in a fluid containing a network of proteins.

 

Can the presence of proteins enhance swimming? For computations, we model the surrounding fluid with the Brinkman equation, representing steady, viscous flow through an array of stationary objects such as proteins/fibers. The model parameter that defines the density of fibers is the resistance parameter; its value increases as the density of fibers increases, which adds resistance to the fluid motion. We model the sperm as a thin, elastic swimmer represented by a collection of smoothed point forces that interact with the fluid.

 

First, we prescribe a specific waveform for the swimmer. Through analysis of many simulations, we determined that in this situation, the swimming speed always increases as the resistance parameter increases. The idea of enhanced swimming with additional fibers seems counter intuitive, however, we found that in order to attain the prescribed amplitude of the waveforms and achieve an enhancement in swimming speed, the amount of work done by the swimmer had to increase dramatically as the resistance parameter increased. Note that prescribing the waveform is equivalent to fixing the amount of work and since most microorganisms aim to minimize work, this model does not inform us about optimal swimming behaviors, but does provide a framework for which to study such optimization.

 

We also investigate the emergent waveforms for a swimmer where, if instead of prescribing the waveform, we prescribe a preferred curvature.  We first developed new computational methods to solve for the relevant fluid flow in the presence of an elastic structure. In the simulations, we observe distinct emergent waveforms and non-monotonic changes in swimming speed as the resistance parameter changes. Enhanced swimming is observed for moderate resistance parameters, in a biologically relevant range of fiber densities. Slower swimming does result for larger resistance parameters since the fibers are preventing the swimmer from moving and thus achieving the preferred curvature. We also varied the stiffness of the elastic swimmers and determined that stiffer swimmers, representative of mammalian sperm, can achieve a swimming enhancement whereas less stiff swimmers such as marine invertebrate sperm do not achieve this enhancement. This leads to the hypothesis that mammalian sperm have adapted to their fluid environment. Our results also show that fluid elasticity is not necessary to see an enhancement in swimming speed, an idea proposed in previous theoretical models.

 

From idealized 2D models to fully 3D models with accurate geometries. Previous theoretical models have considered 2D  frameworks for ease of analysis and efficient computation, and because some microorganism swimming is rather planar. But microorganisms move in 3D environments and so their mostly-planar waveforms does not necessarily restrict them to a 2D plane. We have developed new numerical methods to model the bend and twist of a swimmer in a fluid with resistance. Additionally, since it is computationally expensive to model large numbers of swimmers, we developed a companion method to account for many swimmers using a periodic representation. Using mathematical theory and considering a computational domain that is periodic in all directions, we allow for simulations of thousands of swimmers. Since sperm and other microorganisms often swim in confined geometries, we have also worked to derive a numerical method to calculate the flow near a wall.

 

Intellectual Merit

In this work, we have identified how protein volume fractions affect sperm motility, which we found could either aid or hinder sperm motility. This knowledge can help guide the development of devices such as artificial micro-swimmers, used for drug delivery and bio-sensing. Four new computational methods were developed, which can be used to study microorganisms more generally. This research has led to seven manuscripts, four published and three are currently in review.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has resulted in interdisciplinary training for two undergraduate students, one postdoc, and one graduate student. Many scientific presentations were given at conferences to describe the new computational methods and to emphasize the importance of protein volume fraction on swimming. In addition, talks were given a local high school to get students interested in modeling and computational methods.
